_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Imperial County Department of Health and the State of California have requested that a California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program be prepared for the Heber Geothermal Company (HGC) facility and the Second Imperial Geothermal Company (SIGC) facility, both operated by Ogden Geothermal Operations, Inc., located in Heber, CA.  The CalARP Program satisfies the requirements of the County and the Federal Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 of the Clean Air Act.  Both the HGC facility and the SIGC facility use chlorine in excess of the threshold quantities under 40 CFR Part 68 and Article 2, Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code and Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 of the California Code of Regulations.  The SIGC facility also uses isopentane in excess of the threshold quantity under 40 CFR Part 68 and Article 2, Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code and Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 of the California Code of Regulations. Based on the amount of Regulated Substances (RSs) handled at the facilities and the facilities' PSM requirements, both facilities are subject to the Program 3 requirements for the RMP.

To satisfy the CalARP Program requirements, Ogden Geothermal Operations, Inc. is submitting this RMP and CalARP Program.  Ogden Geothermal Operations, Inc. is also submitting a RMP as required under the Federal guidelines using the RMP Submit program.  The program summarizes the processes involving the RSs handled at the facility and the potential hazards associated with the handling of the RSs.  The approach and technical evaluation methods used to review the RS-handling processes and mitigate the potential hazards are also presented. 

This Program is based on a Process Hazards Analysis, Offsite Consequence Analysis, and Seismic Assessment that were completed to evaluate the processes involving the RS.  The Program also documents recommendations arising from the evaluations and a schedule
